intro: Napus oleracea, commonly known as Chinese cabbage, is a Brassicaceae family plant native to East Asia. It is characterized by its thick, leafy stems and tightly wrapped leaves that form a compact head. The plant typically grows to a height of 30–60 cm and is cultivated for its edible leaves, stems, and flowering parts. It prefers cool climates and well-drained soil, making it a staple in many Asian cuisines. Its botanical features include small white or purple flowers and siliques that contain seeds.
